"Dave Astels " wrote:

> ...on reflection a better way (is to) define the "public interface" by
> making it a Java interface that
> your class implements.  Then make the interface documented and
> available.  Clients must write to the interface, implementation
> details are irrelavant to them, as they should be.

Fascinating approach.

It solves an interesting problem. Java's "public" access modifier
doesn't let
you distinguish between an API which is meant to be published and
available
to a user, and APIs that the implementation needed to be public, but
which
a user shouldn't care about. (Assuming that they can't be made
packatge-private.)

Documenting *only* interfaces would make it possible to define the
"published
subset" of public APIs.

There is one downside, however.

I work with Javadoc, which only publishes its interfaces. Since no spec
is
complete, it requires experimentation to determine many of the
implementation
details. JUnit is a great way to set up experiments. But since there are
no
classes in the published spec, there are no constructors, so it is
extremely
difficult to set up unit tests for experimentation.

It's an unexpected downside to the interface-publishing strategy.
